parameter 1: Syndicated versions were edited to 22 minutes, and are also presented on both the season 1 and season 2 DVD releases. Only a handful of episodes on the DVD releases are presented in their original unedited form.
parameter 2: MTV's website offers longer, uncut versions of some of the skits.

parameter 4: There are at least three different versions of the film, 83 minutes, 90 minutes, and 104 minutes
parameter 5: Syndicated versions were edited to 22 minutes, and are also presented on both the season 1 and season 2 DVD releases. Only a handful of episodes on the DVD releases are presented in their original unedited form.
parameter 6: From 1981 to 1983, a re-edited, half-hour version of this series was shown on Canadian prime time TV under the title Fast Company.
parameter 7: There are at least three different versions of the film, 83 minutes, 90 minutes, and 104 minutes
parameter 8: During their original airings, episodes ran exactly 24 1/2 minutes (not counting commercial time). Most syndication prints now run 22 minutes to allow for additional commercial time. Some of the missing material (which includes the episode epilogues and other miscellaneous scenes) has been restored to VHS and DVD releases of various "Andy Griffith" episodes.
parameter 9: There are at least three different versions of the film, 83 minutes, 90 minutes, and 104 minutes

parameter 12: Some DVD sets of public domain episodes have the classic theme song replaced by generic music due to copyright disputes.

parameter 18: Some DVD sets of public domain episodes have the classic theme song replaced by generic music due to copyright disputes.
parameter 19: Towards the end of the 1970s nostalgia boom, this series was re-released in sepia-tone, with new color wraparounds featuring 'James Brown (II)' (qv) in character as Lt. Masters, "telling" each installment's story to a group of children.
parameter 20: From 1981 to 1983, a re-edited, half-hour version of this series was shown on Canadian prime time TV under the title Fast Company.
parameter 21: In the French version the character names of Face, Murdoch and B.A. were changed to Futé, Looping and Barracuda respectively. Additionally the main title theme was replaced with a French song.
parameter 22: The VHS version cuts approximately two hours out of the movie in order to make it fit on two tapes, as opposed to either three single sided DVD's or one double sided and one single sided DVD in the DVD version.  Most of the cuts taken alone do not constitute major plot elements, but the extent of all of them put together significantly alter the viewing experience from one version to the other.
parameter 23: A re-edited half-hour version called "Prime Cuts" aired in early 1981.
parameter 24: Syndicated versions were edited to 22 minutes, and are also presented on both the season 1 and season 2 DVD releases. Only a handful of episodes on the DVD releases are presented in their original unedited form.
parameter 25: A re-edited half-hour version called "Prime Cuts" aired in early 1981.
parameter 26: In the French version the character names of Face, Murdoch and B.A. were changed to Futé, Looping and Barracuda respectively. Additionally the main title theme was replaced with a French song.
parameter 27: Some DVD sets of public domain episodes have the classic theme song replaced by generic music due to copyright disputes.
parameter 28: From 1981 to 1983, a re-edited, half-hour version of this series was shown on Canadian prime time TV under the title Fast Company.
parameter 29: The episodes broadcast in Germany on the commercial network RTL were heavily cut with regards to violence and 'imitable techniques' (such as improvising weapons and explosives). Also, the opening credits for all episodes were based on the version originally used for the 5th season, including the unpopular remix of the opening song. The first season episodes broadcast on the public network ARD, however, were completely uncut and featured the original opening credits.
